body:
While reviewing the double_to_char function to determine if the size includes null termination, I found that ecvt function is being used to convert the double to character. ecvt function is not thread safe. Can you please fix the surround code too.  

Also, it looks like size shouldn't include null termination.  The refactored code using sprintf can decide how the size should be used
I will create anther PR for 2.3 branch

+1
You can imagine that I didn't look at every changed line, but all the places I checked looked good. Thanks a lot for this big cleanup effort!
Hi Dave. Sorry for that I forget to close this one. Actually I have created a anther PR for this https://github.com/apache/incubator-trafodion/pull/1225
I am running full regressions on this one over the weekend. Please do not merge until I've reported the results.
Looks good to me.  I wonder if there are other parts of SQL where we generate internal syntax that would run into a similar issue.
That is quite possible. I did check the likely places within the ustat code and I believe they are all now covered.
I ran full regressions on this overnight last night on a workstation and all tests passed.
Hi Selva, thank you for your comments.  seems ecvt function is obsolete, sprintf is recommended.  Can I use sprintf to refactor the function double_to_char?
Thank you, appreciate all your replies.

@selvaganesang @sandhyasun 

The part of fetch LOB context is the early work. Now, the JDBC will fetch the whole LOB context once. I planed to improve it. 

The JDBC need implement the  streaming concept. Since the we can't modify the LOB context and only append it. SO for JDBC, it need fetch all the LOB context, and modify it and than write it again.
I need be careful for the code change in JDBC to handle different case.
For example, there are some different case:

For example, The JDBC has already fetch 100 bytes, and the length is 200.
1.  if the application call setBytes(200, data), the JDBC can only append the data.
2.  if the application call setBytes(150, data), the JDBC need fetch anther 50 bytes and update the whole LOB.
2. if the application calls setBytes(50, data), the JDBC can modify the lob context local and then update the whole LOB.

From the example, I think i need handle different case very carefully, so the work need some time to finish.
For now, I think we can tell the use the limitation of the JDBC LOB API.

For anther driver, ODBC Linux is on working.  

JDBC T2 need some rework fro ROWSETS part and then the LOB function will be added.
Previous Test Aborted. New Check Test Started: https://jenkins.esgyn.com/job/Check-PR-master/2047/
Just to reiterate, looks good to me. Thanks for all the replies.

@Sandhyasun explained to me why the changed code can cause the change in current behavior.  Currently, without the lines 6509 - 6514, the JDBC/ODBC application should be able to get the more lob data from the current position. The lines 6509-6514 closes the lob and hence it is not possible for the application to get more lob data.

I would revert back my earlier comment that this change looks ok.  I was under the opinion that the EXTRACT command can be used to extract the lob data from any given position. @Sandhyasun clarified that EXTRACT command can't work that way if the lob cursor is closed. The lines 6509-6514 closes the lob cursor. Hence this change needs to be refactored
